Hey! It was great playing with you guys again (technically against but oh well) on Milstein this year!

I forgot if it was already asked, but what happened during Milstein quals 92?

How was the cutting of the flex wheels determined for each set of rollers?

Can you talk about what these thickened areas of polycarb are on the funnel?

Screenshot 2025-09-08 232613240×930 54.4 KB

How did the grippy studs work? To me it seems they would interfere more than help with the algae, or was it more the upper wheel had enough power to draw the algae in, then the studs just acted like teeth? Did you ever have issues with popping?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":87,"updated_at":"2025-09-09T03:31:04.545Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":1021,"readers_count":1020,"score":279.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":506115,"topic_slug":"team-254-presents-2025-undertow-technical-binder-code-q-a","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52870,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Amateur Historian?"},"post_url":"/t/team-254-presents-2025-undertow-technical-binder-code-q-a/506115/3","custom_user_title":"Amateur Historian?","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3734587,"name":"Ryan Siwinski","username":"rsiwinski","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/df788c/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-09T03:39:59.006Z","cooked":"

Quals 93 was an interesting one, the autoalign was slightly off so a coral bounced off the peg in a way that landed it perfectly in position to switch the main breaker off.

We cut the flexwheels in a semi-arbitrary way except for the front two, for which it was for the frame perimeter.

The thickened areas are when two layers of polycarbonate overlap, and are held together with double sided tape. We did this so we could cut it out of a single piece of polycarbonate.

The stud “teeth” helped grab the algae from the bottom and prevented it from slipping on the polycarbonate. They minimally, if it all, interfered with the grabbing.

We always like to give ourselves options when deciding the robot architecture because we have no idea how the strategy will play out for any particular game. We also did use it a lot at Sacramento and East bay both for autonomous and when the intake broke. Even though we knew we likely wouldn’t use it at the championship, we kept it on as a failsafe in case the intake broke.

At our regionals especially, some teams cough cough 8793 would play some very aggressive defense. This mainly happened when an opponent robot broke so they’d pivot to playing defense to still contribute to the match.

Also, because the intake wasn’t a 4 bar, it was prone to much higher force from frontal and lateral impacts. It didn’t break in this way too often at competitions because our driver did a good job at protecting the intake against defenders and not using it as the collision vessel, but we kept it anyways because it still exploded a couple times at the regionals.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":87,"updated_at":"2025-09-09T04:27:01.881Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":817,"readers_count":816,"score":258.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506115,"topic_slug":"team-254-presents-2025-undertow-technical-binder-code-q-a","display_username":"Ryan Siwinski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":33067,"username":"Aaron_Li","name":"RoboGeek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aaron_li/{size}/10195_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60705,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/team-254-presents-2025-undertow-technical-binder-code-q-a/506115/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"call_me_hand","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3734695,"name":"Jared Russell","username":"Jared_Russell","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jared_russell/{size}/399_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-09T04:31:31.330Z","cooked":"

139 days ago I promised to share more details about our localization and path following approach when we released our code. Well, better late than never!

For localization, we used two Limelight 4’s and fused each camera’s megatag 1 pose estimates with odometry (we found MT1 range estimates were excellent but bearing estimates were poor at range, so we used MT1 range and gyro bearing unless we had multiple tags or were very close) and with each other, with the usual grab-bag of heuristics to decide which estimates to trust vs. not. In general, as long as lighting on the field was not totally awful, our Limelights were actually connected, and were recently calibrated and were kept clean (and each of these conditions was sometimes false), we had excellent state estimation with this approach. We only ever used reef tags, and when scoring we only trusted updates that included the tag on that face.

For planning and control, we used PathPlanner’s on-the-fly paths in both auto and teleop, but wound up substantially modifying much of the implementation to fit our use-case and for improved performance. Key things we changed include:

1. Refactoring pathfinding so that we could stitch a post-pathfinding path onto the pathfinding output directly (without having to reschedule commands between them). [Why: when we score on the reef with our robot, we need to drive into the peg straight]

2. Implementing a path cache (including bezier splines) so that we didn’t need to wait for path regeneration in auto (we would “warm up” auto by precomputing every path we intended to drive to ensure a cache hit). The cache also supported approximate cache hits, in which case the true start state would be re-stitched onto the cached path [Why: 100ms+ time savings in auto per path, absolutely necessary for us to hit our 5 piece]

3. Augmenting the feedforward force calculation in PathPlannerTrajectory to account for centripetal acceleration and weight transfer between wheels due to CG height. [Why: Significantly better trajectory tracking around curves in conjunction with ForceTorqueFOC control on the drive wheels]

4. Implementing a “Path Callback” to dynamically change the constraints on a trajectory as a function of external information (like whether a gamepiece has finished staging, or whether we need to slow down in order to have confidence we’d place accurately enough). [Why: Lets us deal with uncertainty about if we will have a game piece ready to score in time]

5. Improving the shortcutting inside pathfinding (which eliminates intermediate waypoints in the output path if there’s a shorter collision free path between the previous and successive points) to be globally optimal rather than greedy. [Why: significantly more direct paths between the feeder and faces partially around the reef]

  1. Refactored PID trajectory following to be robot relative, which let us put different gains (and therefore priorities) on longitudinal tracking error versus cross-track error. [Why: for our robot, cross-track error was much less forgiving for actually hitting the peg].

7. Did PID control about the coral that we were holding out instead of about the robot’s center of rotation. [Why: the coral is the point we actually care about, and without this compensation heading control actually induces errors in Y due to the lever arm. With the compensation, we also command robot origin relative Y control to counteract the heading action and keep our “tool frame” in place.]

8. Refactored bezier spline creation to account for initial robot velocity by deriving control points from the velocity vector and previewing the starting point for pathfinding along this vector. [Why: We wanted the driver to be able to hit auto align even at full robot speed without discontinuities in the resulting trajectory]

9. Improved robustness of curvature estimation inside path/trajectory planning using the exact analytical derivative of the spline as well as sampling points more densely during high curvature sections. [Why: we noticed that it was sometimes possible for pathplanner to misunderstand the curvature implied by a given sequence of 3 points, and therefore resolve to an acceleration that is entirely too high to be trackable]

10. Added several new parameters to path constraints to allow us to express additional considerations like separate (robot relative) maximum X and Y accelerations. [Why: helps us avoid excessive pitch and roll or inducing oscillation when our elevator is up]

We used 2 12v Pololu Step up/step down converters and 1 5v Polulu step down converter. The can board works as the main junction point for all connections to the protected 12v rail. Most of our sensors, including CAN Ranges, CANdi, and Banner brand Retroreflective sensors, all run off of this protected rail.

Throughout the season, we’re just spitballing ideas but someone makes a slack thread anywhere from 2 weeks to 3 days before the robot reveal. In the thread, anyone can suggest a name that is optimally tied to the game theme. Then, the name is selected off of either student consensus and mentor approval or a mentor picks one they like and nobody stops them. UNDERTOW is a speedboat so it semi-aligns with the DIVE and REEFSCAPE theme.
